item.term: Early first millennium to the fourth century BC (predominance of Saba)
Fourth to first centuries BC (predominance of Qataban and Hadramawt, and their alliance with Main)
First century BC to early second century AD (alliances between the tribes of the high plateau and the ASA kingdoms)
Late second to late third centuries AD (wars among the Himyar, Saba and Hadramawt)
Fourth to sixth centuries AD (unification of Yemen under Himyarite rule)

1.[Shahr Yagill bin Yadaʿ]ʾab, King of Qatabān, has decreed and ordained this binding ordinance (which) 2.[the king, Shahr, had made binding on the trib]e of Qatabān and the clients of the king and their sons and their wives 3.[and their daughters and] their [maidservants] and their man-servants and their dependents and their serfs from this very 4.[… … … all] male and female children who are born in Tamnaʿ and its environs 5.[… … who commits a transgression] with respect to this decree and ordinance, he must expend and surrender 6.[himself and his property to] Shahr. These (things) have (hereby) been decreed in the month of Dhū-Birram the Latter 7.[in the] first [year … … Dhū-Dhar]ʾān, and have been certified as law and signed by the very 8.hand of Shahr.

Shahr Yagill bin Yadaʿʾab, King of Qatabān, has decreed and ordained this binding ordinance which
the king, Shahr, had made binding on the tribe of Qatabān and the clients of the king and their sons and their wives

… … … all male and female children who are born in Tamnaʿ and its environs
… … who commits a transgression with respect to this decree and ordinance, he must expend and surrender
himself and his property to Shahr. These things have hereby been decreed in the month of Dhū-Birram the Latter
in the first year … … Dhū-Dharʾān, and have been certified as law and signed by the very
hand of Shahr.
